jgame.listener

Class ButtonListener

  • java.lang.Object
    • jgame.listener.ButtonListener
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Listener

    public abstract class ButtonListener
extends java.lang.Object
implements Listener
    A listener that allows an object to act as a button. The button behaves according to the following rules:
    • A button has three states: no activity, hovered, and depressed.
    • When the user first moves the mouse into the bounding shape of the object, the button is considered "hovered" and the mouseOver(Context) method is invoked.
    • If the user then moves the mouse away from the button, the button is no longer considered "hovered" and the mouseOut(Context) method is invoked.
    • If the button is "hovered" and the user presses a valid mouse button, the button is considered "pressed" and the mouseDown(Context) method is invoked.
    • If a mouse button is released while the mouse pointer is hovering over the button and the button is "pressed," the button is considered "clicked," the mouseClicked(Context) method is invoked, and the button is set back to the default buttonState.
    • If the mouse button is released while the button is "pressed" but the mouse pointer has since been moved outside of the object's bounding shape (i.e., hover, press, move away, release), the button is not considered "clicked" and the mouseOut(Context) method is invoked.
    Unlike traditional listeners, this class's invoke(GObject, Context) method is declared final and cannot be overridden; subclasses should instead override one or more of the following methods:
    • mouseOver(Context)
    • mouseOut(Context)
    • mouseDown(Context)
    • mouseClicked(Context)
    Author:
    William Chargin

    • Field Detail

      • buttonState

        private ButtonState buttonState
        The current buttonState of this button.

      • validButtonMask

        private int validButtonMask
        The mask for the valid buttons. The default is InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK. If you want to allow more than one button to be valid, use the bitwise or operator, denoted by a single vertical bar or pipe, as follows: | . For example, to allow buttons one and three to fire events, specify the mask as: 
         MouseEvent.BUTTON1_MASK | MouseEvent.BUTTON3_MASK
        Setting this valud to MouseEvent.NOBUTTON will effectively disable this listener.
